LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Armenia

Project Description  The Project follows a sector lending approach and supports the 
Government’s  objective  of  human  development  by  providing 
improved  access  to  sustainable  water  supply  and  sanitation 
(WSS)  services.  The  Project  consists  of  two  components: 
(i) component  A:  municipal  infrastructure  rehabilitation  and 
improvement, and (ii) component B: management improvement 
and  capacity  development.  Component  A  consists  of  about 
18 subprojects,  each  covering  a  cluster  of  small  towns  and 
villages.  Component  B  focuses  on  improving  the  operating 
efficiency  of  WSS  service  providers.  The  Project  will  cover 
16 towns and 125 villages in seven provinces; and provide WSS 
services to about 576,000 people, about 25% of whom are living 
below the poverty line. 
 
Rationale  Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the efficiency of 
  water  management  in  Armenia  declined  because  of  economic 
collapse, inadequate investments, and lack of management skills. 
Consequently, capital investments in infrastructure and operation 
and maintenance of WSS systems throughout the country were 
neglected. Consumers faced serious problems with shortage and 
poor quality of drinking water, and lack of wastewater disposal 
facilities.  At  present,  over  60%  of  the  WSS  infrastructure  in 
50 towns and 300 villages is in very poor condition, and about 
50% of the water and sewer networks needs major rehabilitation 
and/or  replacement.  Mechanical  and  electrical  equipment  is 
obsolete and the system designs and standards are outdated. 
Sewer pipes are broken and clogged, and wastewater treatment 
plants are not operating fully. Unaccounted-for water ranges from 
40%  to  90%  in  various  towns  and  villages,  and  most  people 
receive water for only 2–8 hours a day. Poor sanitation facilities 
and  leaking  sewers  are  creating  serious  health  risks  and 
environmental  hazards.  The  Government  of  Armenia  (the 
Government) has mobilized $170 million of investment in the WSS 
sector from the international donor community for disbursement 
between  1997  and  2011.  Since  there  is  a  considerable  gap 
between the overall needs and available financial resources, the 
Government requested assistance from the Asian Development

ii   
Bank (ADB) for the proposed Project to (i) improve the existing 
average 6 hours of drinking water supply to at least 12 hours for 
all by 2012 with safety and reliability, (ii) ensure safe disposal of 
sewage  from  the  project  area,  and  (iii)  improve  the  operating 
efficiency of water service providers to ensure the sustainability of 
the proposed interventions. By 2020, the Government intends to 
achieve 24-hour supply and 100% coverage of safe drinking water 
(from 88% in 2007), as well as 90% sanitation coverage (from 
60% in 2007).  
To  facilitate  systematic  improvement  of  WSS  services,  the 
Government  approved  a  water  policy  in  2002.  It  subsequently 
introduced institutional and sector reforms by strengthening the 
legislative  and  regulatory  framework,  restructuring  sector 
institutions, and mobilizing financial resources for infrastructure 
improvement. It also approved the following laws: (i) Water Code, 
2002; (ii) Fundamental Provisions of the National Water Policy, 
2005;  and  (iii)  National  Water  Program,  2006.  These  legal 
instruments have provided a foundation for improving the quality 
and efficiency of the WSS systems. 
 
To  manage  and  administer  the  WSS  systems  effectively,  the 
Government  established  five  independent  WSS  operators. 
Armenian Water and Sewerage Company (AWSC) and Yerevan 
Water  and  Sewerage  Company  (YWSC)  are  the  two  main 
operators.  The  other  three  operators  are  small  municipal 
companies responsible for management of WSS systems in their 
municipalities.  
AWSC  is  responsible  for  management  of  WSS  systems  in 
37 towns  and  300  villages.  Since  October  2004,  it  has  been 
managed  by  an  international  private  contractor  through  a 
management  contract.  The  main  reasons  for  deciding  to 
implement a management contract were as follows: (i) tariffs were 
too low to support a commercial operation, and the Government 
needed to increase tariffs progressively or develop a system of 
public  subsidies  compatible  with  private  sector  participation; 
(ii) the regulatory framework was new at that time and needed to 
be experienced before implementing a long-term private sector 
arrangement; (iii) the country lacked a good track record in public-
private partnership; and (iv) the Government was facing difficulties 
getting key stakeholders to agree to the long-term involvement of 
the  private  sector  in  WSS.  Within  the  first  2.5  years,  the 
management  contractor  improved  the  efficiency  of  AWSC—
increasing revenue collection by 24%; decreasing energy costs by 
15%, water losses by 20%, and the number of employees by 
40%; and increasing the number of metered connections by 76%. 
The performance targets in the management contract-controlled 
area for 2008 are 12-hour supply, 98% water safety compliance, 
76%  metered  water  connections,  and  90%  financial  operating 
efficiency. The current management contract will expire in October 
2008 and contains an option to extend for a further 2 years. The

Government is exploring various options for deeper involvement 
of private operators in management of the company, including an 
extension of the current management contract, or establishing a 
long-term lease or concession arrangement.  
YWSC  is  responsible  for  management  of  the  WSS  system  in 
Yerevan (the capital) and 33 nearby villages. Since 2005, YWSC

The Project will cover selected towns and villages under AWSC’s 
responsibility  and  some  selected  villages  under  none  of  the 
operators.  
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  of  the  Project  is  improved  public  health  and 
environment for about 576,000 people living in the project towns 
and villages. The outcome of the Project is improved access to 
sustainable WSS in the project areas. The Project will focus on 
optimizing the operation of existing infrastructure and maximizing 
the operating efficiency of WSS service providers, followed by 
constructing new infrastructure.

Implementation  A  project  coordination  unit  (PCU)  will  be  established  within 
Arrangements  SCWS. A project management unit (PMU) will be established in 
  AWSC.  The  PMU,  supported  by  technical  and  management 
  consultants,  will  be  responsible  for  subproject  identification, 
  designs, construction supervision, and improvement of operational 
  efficiency and management of AWSC and the user communities. 
  The PCU will appraise the feasibility studies of the subprojects. A 
  project governing council (PGC) will be established at SCWS to 
  monitor  project  implementation  and  ensure  consistency  with 
  government  policies  and  programs.  The  Government  plans  to 
  prepare,  appraise,  and  award  all  the  contracts  within  the  first 
  2.5 years. 
   
Procurement  All procurement financed under the Project will be carried out in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Contracts for civil works estimated to 
cost  more  than  $1  million  equivalent  and  contracts  for  goods 
estimated to cost more than $500,000 equivalent will be procured 
using international competitive bidding (ICB). Civil works contracts 
estimated to cost $1 million equivalent or less will be procured 
through  national  competitive  bidding  (NCB).  Goods  contracts 
estimated to cost between $100,000 and $500,000 equivalent will 
be procured through NCB. Goods contracts estimated to cost less 
than $100.000 equivalent will be carried out through shopping 
procedures.  Goods  valued  below  $10,000  may  be  purchased 
directly from the supplier. 
 
Consulting Services  Inputs of 1,120 person-months of national consultants are planned 
for project implementation and management support to the PCU 
and PMU. This type of consulting services is not new to Armenia 
and national consultants have already been providing high quality 
and  cost-effective  services.  The  selection  and  engagement  of 
these consulting services will be in accordance with the quality 
and cost-based selection method of ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
Project Benefits and  The  Project  is  expected  to  benefit  16  towns  and  about 
Beneficiaries  125 villages with an overall population of about 576,000 people, 
  25% of whom are living below the poverty line. The Project will 
improve  public  health  and  environment  in  project  towns  and 
villages.  Related  benefits  include  time  and  cost  savings  from 
purchasing,  fetching,  treating,  and  storing  water;  improved 
hygiene  and  health;  reduced  medical  outlays;  and  increased 
productive  days.  The  Project  will  support  improvements  in 
technical and financial capacities, and operational efficiency of the 
service providers.

v
Risks and Assumptions  Potential risks associated with the Project include the following: 
(i) start-up delays may occur because AWSC is unfamiliar with the 
use of ADB’s Procurement Guidelines, (ii) delays may occur in 
agreed improvements to be made in financial and legal reforms, 
and (iii) the upward adjustment in tariffs may not be supported by 
all communities.   
 
The  Project  includes  the  following  measures  to  mitigate  these 
risks: (i) during the Loan Fact-Finding Mission, AWSC was given 
detailed  orientation  on  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  and 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. AWSC has already initiated 
advance procurement actions under ADB’s guidance. AWSC will 
be further trained during the Loan Inception Mission; (ii) ADB’s 
policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  has  focused  on  sector 
improvements  and  reforms.  To  ensure  compliance,  the 
Government  will  hold  PGC  meetings  quarterly  to  monitor 
implementation of these reforms within the agreed time frame. 
The ADB team will consistently follow up and work closely with the 
Government on the agreed actions; and (iii) the public outreach 
program—including  media  campaign,  community  mobilization, 
and public workshops—will be implemented to achieve community 
awareness and ownership in service delivery. Under this program, 
beneficiaries will be involved in planning, designing, implementing, 
and operation and maintenance of the subprojects. Communities 
will be educated in proper water and hygiene practices, and in 
their  responsibilities  as  beneficiaries  to  pay  for  the  improved 
services.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Armenia for the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Armenia is a mountainous landlocked country located in the southern Caucasus. It has a 
land area of approximately 28,700 square kilometers and shares land borders with Azerbaijan, 
Georgia,  Iran,  and  Turkey.  Based  on  National  State  Statistics  Association  estimates,  the 
population was about 3.22 million in 2006 of which about 64% lives in urban areas and the 
remainder in rural villages. About half the urban population lives in Yerevan, the capital city. The 
population is forecast to grow at 0.3% per annum through 2015. For administrative purposes, 
Armenia is divided into 10 marzes (provinces) that are subdivided into districts, and consist of 
towns and villages. The proportion of the population living in poverty was 29.8% in 2005. Most 
of the country’s poor lives in regional towns where the incidence of poverty is about 38%. 
3.  To  improve  people’s  living  standards,  the  environment,  and  public  health,  the 
Government  of  Armenia  (the  Government)  is  prioritizing  improved  delivery  of  water  and 
sanitation (WSS) services. To address serious difficulties being faced by the majority of the 
population because of unsafe and unreliable water supply and inadequate sanitation facilities, 
the Government has mobilized financial resources, strengthened the legislative and regulatory 
framework, and restructured sector institutions. Since there is a considerable gap between the 
overall needs and available financial resources, the Government requested assistance from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to prepare the proposed Project. ADB approved a small-scale 
technical assistance1 (TA) and fielded a Loan Fact-Finding Mission from 29 May to 15 June 
2007.  This  report  is  based  on  the  TA  report  and  the  Mission’s  understanding  with  the 
Government. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.    
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
4.  Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the efficiency of WSS management in 
Armenia  declined  because  of  economic  collapse,  inadequate  investments,  and  lack  of 
management  skills.  Consequently,  capital  investments  in  infrastructure  and  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of WSS systems throughout the country were neglected. Consumers faced 
serious problems with shortage and poor quality of drinking water, and lack of wastewater 
disposal facilities. At present, over 60% of the WSS infrastructure in 50 towns and 300 villages 
is  in  very  poor  condition,  and  about  50%  of  the  water  and  sewer  networks  need  major 
rehabilitation  and/or  replacement.  In  several  towns  and  villages,  mechanical  and  electrical 
equipment is obsolete, and the system designs and standards are outdated. Sewer pipes are 
broken and clogged, and wastewater treatment plants are not operating fully. Unaccounted-for 
water (UFW) ranges from 40% to 90% and most people receive water for only 2–8 hours a day. 
Poor sanitation facilities and leaking sewers are creating serious health risks and environmental 
hazards. 
5.  The sector performance indicators for 2006 show the following:  
(i)  About 88% of the population has access to drinking water supply. Out of this, 75% 
has access to piped water supply. About 15% receives 24-hour services and others 
receive intermittent water supply for 2–8 hours. The remaining 12% has no access 
to safe drinking water and relies on unsafe water sources. In rural areas, about 51%

or  public  standpipes.  Drinking  water  is  drawn  mainly  (96%)  from  groundwater

(ii)  In urban areas, about 60% of households have access to sanitation services but the

(iii)  The operating efficiency2 of water service providers ranges from 25% to 40%,

pumps, high cost of electricity, and lack of system maintenance. The high level of 
UFW  is  due  to  system  leakages,  illegal  connections,  and  service  payment 
defaulters.  
6.  To facilitate systematic improvement of WSS services, the Government approved a 
water  policy  in  2002.  It  subsequently  introduced  institutional  and  sector  reforms  by 
strengthening the legislative and regulatory framework, restructuring sector institutions, and 
mobilizing financial resources for infrastructure improvement. It also adopted an important water 
policy and legal framework comprising the following: (i) Water Code, 2002; (ii) National Water 
Policy, 2005; and (iii) National Water Program, 2006. This framework covers, among others, the 
establishment of water management institutions; the principles of integrated water management 
and river basin management; management, protection, and conservation of water resources; 
supervision  of  water  standards  and  reserves;  security  of  adequate  water  supply  to  the 
population and the economy; and mandatory preparation of short, medium, and long-term 
investment  programs.  This  provides  the  foundation  for  the  policy,  and  the  sustainable 
management and operation of the WSS systems. The main principles of the National Water 
Policy relevant to the WSS sector are (i) provision of safe drinking water of the required quantity 
and  sanitation  to  meet  the  basic needs  of all  the  population,  including  socially  vulnerable 
groups; (ii) efficient management of water resources and water systems by the application of 
water  pricing  criteria;  (iii)  assuring  the  gradual  introduction  of  a  24-hour  water  supply; 
(iv) maintaining sanitary and hygienic standards; (v) assuring water resources management 
through  “user  pays”  and  “polluter  pays”  principles  and  cost  recovery  approaches;  and 
(vi) managing water resources and water systems in a transparent and participatory manner, 
assuring gender policy principles and public participation processes. The summary of the WSS 
sector policy is in Appendix 2, the summary of the sector road map is in Appendix 3, and the 
sector investment plan in Supplementary Appendix A. 
7.  In January 2004, the Government adopted the Law on Regulatory Body for Public 
Services which entrusted the Public Services Regulatory Commission with the authority to 
regulate public utilities in the energy, water, and telecommunications sectors. The law sets an 
enabling legal framework for an independent agency responsible for setting fair and just tariffs in 
a transparent and sustainable manner.

8.  The Government’s law on local self-government delegates responsibility for providing 
WSS services to the local level. Local town municipalities and village administrations own the 
water distribution networks within their administrative areas. The state owns the water resources 
and main infrastructure from source to the town or village entry point, and delivers bulk water 
through established WSS companies. Town municipalities and village administrations can either 
(i) buy bulk water from the water company and manage the distribution networks themselves, 
which only works well when town municipalities and village administrations have adequate 
capacity and the WSS is simple to operate; or (ii) enter into an agreement with the water 
company to manage the WSS systems and collect the water tariff directly from individual 
consumers. Town municipalities and village administrations in general lack the managerial and 
technical capacity and financial resources to manage WSS systems, so they are gradually 
adopting option (ii).  
9.  The legislation has enabled restructuring of the sector institutions. The State Committee 
of Water Systems (SCWS) was established as a key sector governing body. Its responsibilities 
include  (i)  management,  operation,  and  safe  use  of  all  state-owned  WSS  systems; 
(ii) participation  in  preparation  and  implementation  of  the  National  Water  Program;  and 
(iii) development and implementation of the water sector investment policy and programs. To 
discharge  its  duties  and  responsibilities,  SCWS  has  established  five  independent  WSS 
companies. Yerevan Water and Sewerage Company (YWSC) covers the capital city and 33 
nearby villages. The Armenian Water and Sewerage Company (AWSC) delivers service to 37 
towns and about 300 villages throughout the country. Shirak Water and Sewerage Company 
(SWSC), Lori Water and Sewerage Company (LWSC), and Nor Akunq Water and Sewerage 
Company (NWSC) are small regional service providers for towns and villages in their respective 
regions. 
10.  YWSC is a commercial company managed and operated through a lease contract by an 
international water utility operator. The three regional water companies are owned 51% by the 
Government and 49% by the respective municipalities, and are operated and managed as 
public municipal entities. AWSC is owned by the Government, and has 4 regional branches and 
34  sector  units  spread  over  the  country.  It  has  an  experienced  and  well-trained  team  of 
engineers, financial managers, and technical specialists; and has been managed through a 
management contract by an international water utility operator since 2004. The main reasons for 
deciding to implement a management contract were as follows: (i) tariffs were too low to support 
a  commercial  operation,  and  the  Government  needed  to  increase  tariffs  progressively  or 
develop  a  system  of  public  subsidies  compatible  with  private  sector  participation;  (ii)  the 
regulatory framework was new at that time and needed to be experienced before implementing 
a long-term private sector arrangement; (iii) the country lacked a good track record in public-
private partnership; and (iv) the Government was facing difficulties convincing key stakeholders 
to agree to long-term involvement of the private sector in WSS. Within the first 2.5 years, the 
management contractor improved the efficiency of AWSC—increasing revenue collection by 
24%; decreasing energy costs by 15%, water losses by 20%, and the number of employees by 
40%; and increasing the number of metered connections by 58%.4 The performance targets in 
the  management  contract-controlled  area  for  2008  are  12-hour  supply,  98%  water  safety 
compliance,  76%  metered  water  connections,  and  90%  financial  operating  efficiency.  The 
current management contract will expire in October 2008 and contains an option to extend for 
further 2 years. The Government is exploring various options for deeper involvement of private 
operators in management of the company, including extension of the current management 
contract, or establishing a long-term lease or concession arrangement. A team of experts 
financed by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) will review the

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
11.  Municipal Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Improvement. The degraded condition of 
WSS infrastructure throughout the country and the high level of UFW are major contributors to 
the poor quality of service and high operating costs. The overdesigned and aging WSS systems 
have  made  it  impossible  to  operate  the  WSS  systems  efficiently  and  effectively.  The 
Government’s main priority is to improve people’s living standard by providing them with basic 
services, mainly safe and reliable water supply and improved sewerage facilities. This will be 
achieved through financial investments and effective management in (i) water supply, focusing 
as a first priority on optimal use of the existing infrastructure by rehabilitating and replacing the 
deteriorated water supply infrastructure, reducing leakage, and improving supply pressure; then 
extending new mains to reinforce supply to new consumers and installing water meters to all 
consumers; and (ii) sewerage improvement by cleaning existing sewers and carrying out urgent 
repairs of damaged sewers that are polluting water supply in selected towns and villages, and 
extension of sewers to new consumers, followed by wastewater treatment.  
12.  Operational  and  Financial  Management.  In  general,  the  WSS  companies  have 
sufficient  managerial  and  technical  capability,  but  suffer  from  a  centralized  management 
structure that lacks clearly defined statements of functions, duties and responsibilities, and 
operating procedures. To become sustainable, companies need to improve their operational 
efficiency,  reform  their  management  structure,  and  introduce  cost-saving  and  revenue-
improving measures to make operations more efficient and cost-effective.   
13.  Sound financial management is the key to improving the operating efficiency of the water 
supply companies. Financial management needs to be improved in two main areas: (i) revenue 
collection,  which  can  be  increased  by  (a)  reforming  billing  and  collection  procedures; 
(b) updating the consumer database to register all new and illegal consumers, and classifying 
customers by their payment history and targeting intermittent payers and persistent non-payers 
with  public  outreach  programs,  and  granting  legal  powers  to  companies  to  enforce  a 
disconnection  policy  for  defaulters  of  WSS  bills,  and  metering  all  the  connections;  and 
(ii) operating costs, which can be reduced by introducing improved cost control and budgeting 
systems and procedures and by implementing cost reduction techniques. Prime areas for cost 
reduction include reducing electricity costs and eliminating redundant administrative costs.       
14.  Tariff Reform. The sector urgently needs a clear and transparent system of tariff setting 
to take into account the service costs and impact of inflation. At present, an inflexible tariff 
structure applies a standard rate across the country. The cost of supplying water from a source 
that requires pumping is higher than the cost of supplying water by gravity. This cost difference 
is not reflected in the tariff, so there is an internal cross-subsidy as consumers in low production 
cost areas subsidize consumers in high production cost areas. In general, the tariffs are low and 
the tariff structure is not adequate. Further, the Government has to subsidize the revenue

WSS operations, there is an urgent need to rationalize existing tariffs with an adequate tariff

and introduce a tariff plan that includes progressive tariff revision, taking into account service

15.  Service  Delivery  Targets.  The  Government  aims  to  achieve  the  Millennium 
Development Goals with respect to WSS and by 2015, halve the number of people who are 
currently without access to safe water and adequate sanitation. SCWS is updating the sector 
strategy for providing safe and reliable water supply to the population in three stages: 
 
(i)  For poor rural communities in remote areas, which are not covered by existing 
service providers, the target is to provide a basic lifeline supply of 50 liters per capita 
per day (lpcd) through public standpipes located not more than 100 meters from the 
house.  
(ii)  For towns and villages, where safe drinking water can be supplied by the local water 
company, the target for 2012 is piped water supply for at least 12 hours per day with 
cost recovery through the tariff sufficient to cover O&M costs. 
(iii)  The ultimate target for 2020 is to provide 24-hour water supply to all towns and 
villages, with adequate pressure and full cost recovery. 
16.  Policy Dialogue. ADB’s policy dialogue with the Government has focused on (i) cost 
recovery and tariff reforms by (a) rationalizing existing low tariffs and implementing a tariff plan 
that includes progressive tariff revision to ensure full cost recovery and adequate funds for loan 
repayment;  (b)  eliminating  government  subsidy  on  tariffs;  (c)  granting  legal  powers  to 
companies to enforce disconnection policy for defaulters of WSS bills to improve collection 
efficiency, deter nonpayment, and ensure the sustainability of WSS operations; (ii) enterprise 
reforms and corporate governance, ensuring full autonomy for AWSC to manage and operate 
WSS services without any outside interference, disseminate annual reports on its operation and 
development each year, and implement a systematic program of organization development; 
(iii) water conservation through metering all the connections and urgently reducing UFW; and 
(iv)  institutionalization  of  community-based  operations  to  address  the  existing  problem  of 
unclear ownership of systems in villages and weak management for O&M. 
17.  External Assistance. The Government has attracted investments in the WSS sector 
from  the  international  donor  community  amounting  to  about  $170  million  for  disbursement 
between  1997  and  2011.  Yerevan  has  received  about  $56  million  and  the  other  regions 
$114 million. The proposed Project will be the first WSS project financed by ADB in Armenia.   
18.  The World Bank has supported projects for Yerevan water supply, municipal water and 
wastewater, and rural dam safety. German development cooperation through Kreditanstalt für 
Wiederaufbau (KfW) has invested in the three regional water supply companies. The Japan 
Social Development Fund has implemented a community water supply project and Millennium 
Challenge Corporation is supporting irrigation infrastructure. EBRD has approved a project for 
Lake  Sevan  environmental  protection  and  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  is 
undertaking a feasibility study on rural water supply and sanitation. The United States Agency 
for International Development is planning a water supply project for two small towns. Further 
details are in Appendix 4.   
19.  Lessons  Learned.  A  review  of  ADB-wide  experience  with  rehabilitation  assistance 
indicates that projects should (i) be prepared promptly, (ii) focus on infrastructure investment in 
combination with management improvement, (iii) feature a flexible implementation process,

6 
(iv) provide  strong  consulting  support  and  ADB  supervision  during  implementation,  (v)  be 
supported by prompt government action, (vi) ensure that decision making on core issues of 
project design and implementation be decentralized to achieve timely project preparation and 
implementation, and (vii) ensure that intensive consultations with all stakeholders are held and 
all the required information is disseminated during preparation and implementation of projects.    
20.  Since this is ADB’s first project in the WSS sector in Armenia, it has no direct experience 
in  this  sector  in  Armenia.  However,  experience  from  other  externally  assisted  projects  in 
Armenia shows that (i) the well-developed legal and regulatory framework enables smooth 
implementation  of  sector  reforms,  (ii)  decentralization  of  water  sector  operations  and 
management through the creation of area-based water companies is effective and can deliver 
improvements in the key sector performance indicators, (iii) improvements in service delivery 
alone  do  not  necessarily  yield  increased  revenue,  and  (iv)  public  outreach  programs  to 
persuade people to pay, and enforceable sanctions against persistent non-payers are needed. 
ADB’s  experience  in  similar  projects  in  other  regions  shows  that  improvements  in  O&M, 
including  specific  programs  to  reduce  levels  of  UFW,  represent  a  cost-effective  and 
environmentally  responsible  approach  to  water  management  and  should  form  essential 
components of future ADB-financed projects. The proposed Project has been carefully designed 
to reflect each of these lessons. 
21.  Sector Loan Approach. The Project could not be processed as a standard project loan 
because of the large number of relatively small subprojects that are geographically dispersed 
and needed to be implemented urgently. The sector loan approach is based on the following. 
(i)  The  Government’s  sector  policies,  development  objectives,  and  approach  to 
regional WSS systems development are well formulated. Progress in implementing 
policies  has  been  satisfactory  and  the  Government  is  consistently  updating  its 
sector policies with donor support. 
(ii)  Sector  institutions  are  well  developed  and  their  capacity  will  strengthen  with 
additional  strengthening  and  support  provided  under  the  Project.  SCWS,  the 
Executing Agency (EA), and AWSC, the Implementing Agency (IA), have substantial 
experience of implementing similar projects. 
(iii)  The  sector  investment  plan  and  planned  subprojects  are  well  conceived  and

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
23.  The  impact  of  the  Project  is  improved  public  health  and  environment  for  about 
576,000 people living in 16 towns and about 125 villages through safe and reliable water supply 
and improved sewerage and sanitation facilities. The Project will help the Government provide 
the required institutional and management support to AWSC and local municipal governments 
to enable them to be more self-disciplined in financial, managerial, and technical aspects. 
24.  The  outcome  is  improved  access  to  safe,  reliable,  and  sustainable  WSS  services 
managed on commercial principles and environmentally sound practices. The Project will focus 
first  on  optimizing  the  operation  of  existing  infrastructure  and  maximizing  the  operating 
efficiency of WSS service providers, followed by constructing new infrastructure.

25.  The Government provided a list of indicative 18 subprojects covering towns and villages 
where there is a desperate need for urgent WSS improvements (Appendix 5). The project team 
reviewed the feasibility studies of two candidate subprojects. One represents a typical provincial

B.  Outputs 
26.  The  Project  comprises  the  following  main  components:  (i)  municipal  infrastructure 
rehabilitation and improvement, and (ii) management improvement and development.  
1.   Component A:  Municipal Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Improvement 
27.  This  component  comprises  two  parts:  (i)  rehabilitation  and  extension  of  distribution 
systems, and (ii) improvement of sewerage systems. The first part will address rehabilitation 
and replacement of the deteriorated water supply infrastructure by reducing leakage; improving 
supply pressure; constructing new mains to connect new consumers, particularly poorly served 
low-income  communities;  installing  water  meters  to  all bulk  and  domestic  consumers,  and 
repairing/remodeling  water  intakes,  pumps,  flow  meters,  valves,  and  treatment  units;  and 
providing new storage reservoirs and tubewells at technically viable locations. The second part 
will address improvement of the sewerage system by cleaning existing sewers and carrying out 
urgent repairs/replacement of damaged sewers that are polluting water supply in selected towns 
and villages. This part also includes the provision of sewer cleaning machinery and other 
essential equipment required for efficiently operating WSS systems.    
28.  By  redesigning  the  overall  WSS  systems,  this  component  addresses  the  existing 
problems  of  the  systems  being  overdesigned/under-designed.  It  also  includes  updating  of 
consumer databases, conversion of illegal connections to registered accounts, and monitoring 
of water quality. To demonstrate 100% water supply coverage, 100% metering, 24-hour water 
supply with the desired pressure, and 100% collection efficiency, the Project will select a pilot 
zone  and  concentrate  resources  to  undertake  the  related  actions.  This  will  help  gain  the 
confidence of all consumers in the project area in an efficient and strongly governed WSS 
system, and help the IA to replicate it smoothly. Selection of the pilot zone will be based on 
active participation and strong commitment of the users, apart from technical considerations to 
isolate the zone hydraulically for the required water pressure after addressing all the water 
losses.        
2.  Component B: Management Improvement and Capacity Development 
29.  This  component  addresses  core  issues  and  challenges  being  faced  by  AWSC, 
municipalities,  and  communities  in  managing  the  WSS  systems  efficiently.  Management 
efficiency will be improved by a combination of technical, financial, legal, and public outreach 
measures. The overall tasks to be carried out are as follows. 
   a.  Improvement of Operating Efficiency of AWSC 
30.  Planned interventions are (i) training in technical and financial management for AWSC 
staff,  including  mapping  and  asset  management;  (ii)  improving  the  financial  management 
system by introducing improved accounting procedures, computerized billing, and management 
information systems (including budgeting, inventory of assets and staffing, O&M of assets, 
billing,  revenue  collection,  and  reporting  systems);  (iii)  rationalizing  existing  tariffs  and

introducing a tariff plan that includes progressive tariff revision by including inflation and cost of 
services; (iv) measures for cost reduction such as electricity and redundant administrative costs; 
(v) increasing public awareness on water quality and sustainability of facilities, and options for 
improving delivery of WSS services; and (vi) improving regulatory systems to ensure that laws, 
standards, rules, and regulations are equitably and consistently applied. Wherever possible, 
technical training will be linked to measurable outputs to help determine whether skill levels 
have  been  achieved  and  technical  training  is  applied.  The  design  and  implementation  of 
measures for improved municipal management will be coordinated with ongoing projects funded 
by other donors. 
31.  Under  this  subcomponent,  AWSC  will  receive  assistance  to  strengthen  the  service 
contracts  between  the  company  and  municipal  governments  on  the  use  of  locally  owned 
distribution networks, and between the company and communities taking a bulk water supply—
to define the relationship between the parties better. A disconnection policy for non-payers will 
be framed to formulate proposals for empowering AWSC to implement this policy, and an 
incentive plan will be prepared for regular payers. A human resource development strategy will 
be furnished, which will include rightsizing and training of staff and improved business rules. 
This will clearly define the functions, duties, and responsibilities of the management structure 
giving it autonomy to manage the systems independently. A public outreach program will be 
implemented  to  achieve  community  ownership  in  service  delivery.  Under  this  program, 
beneficiaries will be approached for their involvement in planning, designing, implementing, and 
O&M of the subprojects. Communities will be educated in proper water and hygiene practices, 
and their responsibilities as beneficiaries to pay for the improved services. It will be ensured that 
good practices and lessons are disseminated both within Armenia and in other regions.  
32.  This  subcomponent  will  support  AWSC’s  plan  of  organizational  restructuring  and 
performance improvement, which will result in establishing and streamlining operations of the 
financial, technical, and asset management and procurement directorates.  
b.  Improvement of Communities’ Management Skills 
33.  This subcomponent will build the capacity of communities to operate, manage, and 
maintain  their  own  small-scale  WSS  systems  effectively  in  a  sustainable  manner.  Major 
activities will comprise (i) training programs in technical management and operation of small 
water  systems,  including  water  source  protection;  (ii)  preparation  of  manuals  in  the  local 
language for regular sampling, testing, and treatment of drinking water; (iii) basic WSS system 
maintenance and repair, and reporting to AWSC for assistance in case of major breakdowns; 
(iv)  improved  financial  management,  including  budgeting,  billing  and  collection,  and 
bookkeeping; and (v) overall system administration.  
C.  Special Features 
34.  Optimization of Existing Infrastructure. The Project will adopt a logical sequence of 
interventions.  Since  large  investments  already  made  on  the  existing  infrastructure  are  not 
delivering efficient services, the primary focus will be on optimizing the operation of existing 
infrastructure and maximizing the operating efficiency of WSS service providers, instead of 
upfront  construction  of  new  infrastructure.  This  will  allow  the  Project  to  economize  the 
investment, achieve considerable development impacts, and ensure sustainability of the WSS 
system with sound technical and financial management.    
35.  Pilot Zoning. To demonstrate 100% water supply coverage, 100% metering, 24-hour 
water supply, and 100% collection efficiency, the Project will select a pilot zone and fix all the 
identified problems related to physical interventions and improved governance. This will help 
gain the confidence of consumers in the project area in an efficient and strongly governed WSS

project areas.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Environmental Impacts and Benefits 
60.  Overall,  the  Project  provides  environmental  benefits  by  improving  sanitation  and 
providing  safe,  reliable  water  supply  to  towns,  villages,  and  communities.  Two  initial 
environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  were  carried  out  (Supplementary  Appendix  G)  in 
accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), Environmental Assessment Guidelines,6 
and Armenian environmental guidelines. One IEE was prepared for a provincial town and the 
other for a group of five village communities.  
61.  The  IEEs  demonstrated  that  towns  and  communities  in  Armenia  have  WSS 
infrastructure in dire need of rehabilitation. The sample town showed that 70% of the total water 
supplied  is  lost  through  leakage.  In  addition,  water  supply  is  only  available  for  typically             
4–6 hours a day because electricity is costly. Furthermore, rural communities have not had 
constant water supply in more than 15 years. Since then, they buy water delivered by tankers 
from bigger communities or manually transport water from springs. 
62.  To improve the WSS systems, the Project includes the construction and rehabilitation of 
water supply mains and distribution pipelines, repair of water pump stations, construction and 
rehabilitation of sewer pipelines, and construction and repair of water storage reservoirs. These 
physical  improvements  do  not  pose  any  significant  adverse  environmental  effects.  The 
proposed sources, both spring and groundwater, demonstrate good water quality. 
63.  The screening process carried out for the IEEs has identified minor possible adverse 
environmental impacts likely to be caused by the Project. Most potential negative impacts may 
occur during construction. However, they will be temporary and can be mitigated to acceptable 
levels. Effort will be made to (i) protect the sources, (ii) minimize construction pollution and 
waste,  and  (iii)  limit  specific  impacts  related  to  the  pipeline  routes.  A  summary  IEE  is  in 
Appendix 12. 
64.  To  ensure  environmentally  sustainable  implementation  of  the  subprojects,  an 
environmental assessment and review procedure was prepared in accordance with applicable

B.  Social Dimensions 
1.  Poverty Reduction and Social Benefits 
65.  Poverty and social analysis was conducted during project preparation. The Project will 
benefit a total population of about 576,000 people (of which 49% live in regional towns and 51% 
in rural communities) through safe drinking water and improved sanitation. Of the total, about 
140,000 beneficiary households (about 25% of the households) are poor and receive poverty 
family  benefit.  The  poverty  reduction  and  strategy  paper 7   highlights  the  importance  of 
investments in basic rural infrastructure. It gives priority to the construction and rehabilitation of 
rural roads, optimization of health and educational facilities, improving access to safe and 
reliable drinking water, ensuring 24-hour supply and improving the quality of the water supply, 
and an irrigation program aimed at increasing the share of irrigated land and regulation of the 
irrigation  water  supply  systems.  A  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in 
Appendix 13 and details are in Supplementary Appendix I. 
66.  The Project will support poverty reduction by (i) reducing the incidence of waterborne 
diseases, costs of medical care, and sick days taken—reducing household health expenditures; 
(ii) decreasing the workload for women in the house—providing the opportunity for them to 
become more involved in social and economic activities; (iii) providing safer and more reliable 
water supplies; (iv) improving the quality of life of the urban and rural population, particularly the 
poor, by increasing their access to safe drinking water and improving hygiene and sanitation. 
67.  A survey and interviews were conducted with key stakeholders, including consumer 
organizations,  SWSC  employees,  and  condominiums.  The  results  indicated  that  people’s 
priorities  for  the  Project  included  improving  (i)  hours  and  quality  of drinking  water  supply, 
(ii) basic  sanitation,  (iii)  service  affordability  for  socially  vulnerable  groups,  and  (iv)  public 
awareness programs and participatory schemes.  
68.  Armenia’s social protection for the poor includes a family benefit program that assists 
about 30% people below the poverty line.8 The ongoing meter installation program has enabled 
households  to  reduce  water  service  expenditure  significantly.  The  affordability  analysis 
undertaken during the TA indicates that expenditure for water is within acceptable international 
standards of 2–5% of household income. Awareness and education programs related to water 
sector development issues—such as water conservation, tariff increase, and promoting public 
hygiene—will be part of the project implementation. Social indicators (such as accessibility of 
water supply services to all social groups), gender, and health indicators related to waterborne 
diseases will be assessed through socioeconomic surveys and monitored annually as part of 
the PPMS.

3.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
71.  An initial resettlement due diligence screening shows that the Project will not have any 
resettlement issues. All possible resettlement needs were assessed in accordance with ADB’s 
Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995)  and  were  evaluated  in  terms  of  the  proposed

rights-of-way assigned to municipal infrastructure.

D.  Economic Analysis 
74.  The  economic  analysis  was  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Economic Analysis of Projects;9 and covers the economic rationale for government intervention, 
and goals and general design of the water supply sector investment plan (Appendix 14). The 
economic rationale is sound, based on social responsibility to provide basic social services and 
controlling natural monopoly in drinking water supply. The goals of the investment plan are to 
(i) meet targets for water supply development, aiming for expanded service in both urban and 
rural  communities,  including  border  areas  strategic  to  national  security;  (ii)  increase 
collaboration between the Government and the private sector; and (iii) improve the general 
health and well-being of the inhabitants, and increased awareness of the environment/ecology. 
The  targets  of  the  investment  are  clearly  defined,  legally  established,  and  consistent  with 
government goals for sustainable development in water supply as reflected in the water supply 
and sanitation investment plan covering 2000–2012. The plan to meet the targets is based on 
water supply systems designed using least-cost solutions to best fit economies of scale; and 
based on type and availability of water resources, different design technologies, locations, and 
planning  horizons.  Other  project  goals  consistent  with  the  Government’s  water  policy  as 
embodied in the Water Code include economic tools for water resources management and 
protection, cost recovery and sustainability tariffs, conservation and economic use of water, and 
efficient decentralized management. 
75.  Economic analysis of the two candidate subprojects was undertaken as representative 
of  the  subprojects  included  in  the  sector  investment  plan.  The  major  economic  benefits 
assumed  are  based  on  resource  cost  savings  from  time  spent  by  households  on  water 
collection.  Data  on  time  savings  for  water  collection  are  based  on  focus  discussions  with 
potential  beneficiaries  in  the  subproject  communities.  The  discussions  aided  in  eliciting 
information on the estimated time spent by household members collecting water from available 
sources, based on distance traveled and the average number of times the activity is performed 
each day. Data on average family income and minimum wages in the locality have been used to 
value the cost of the activity. The economic costs, consisting of capital investment and operating 
costs, have been converted from financial costs using shadow pricing. The conversion factors 
applied are based on infrastructure projects of similar scope in the Central Asian region. The 
results of the analysis show that undertaking the subprojects will result in an economic internal 
rate of return (EIRR) of 25% for Abovyan and 17.3% for Ararat. Tested under adverse economic 
conditions, the subprojects will yield EIRR exceeding the Economic Opportunity Cost of Capital 
at 12%. The benefit-cost ratio is 1.26 for the Abovyan subproject and 1.27 for the Ararat 
subproject. Other benefits that cannot be quantified will accrue in general terms to economic 
development of the project areas as a result of improved water supply and sanitation. These 
include increased economic activities and output of commerce and industry, and improved 
operations of institutions such as schools and hospitals that require safe and sufficient water 
supply.  Economic  benefits  will  likewise  accrue  from,  among  others,  increased  consumer 
satisfaction; increased health benefits caused by disease prevention and a reduction in mortality 
rate; and increased fire protection, especially in crowded settlements and commercial areas. 
 
E.  Financial Evaluation 
76.  Financial analysis for the two subprojects was also undertaken. The analysis was based 
on estimates using first quarter 2007 prices and demand projections consistent with existing 
levels. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms after tax were 
converted into real terms by adjusting for foreign and domestic inflation and currency fluctuation.

77.  Financial  projections  were  prepared  for  the  subprojects  in  accordance  with  ADB’s

F.  Affordability Analysis and Project Sustainability 
78.  The subprojects will be prepared through the active participation of target beneficiaries 
from the initial stage of planning, design, and construction. Villages that will not join the AWSC 
service zone will be responsible for O&M of the local schemes. Based on the sample focused 
discussions in the Ararat subproject with five villages, there is an apparent willingness among 
the population to avail of and pay for improved water supplies. In towns and communities that 
are currently under AWSC service jurisdiction and where water service is deficient, willingness 
to  pay  for  improved  water  supply  service  is  high.  The  affordability  analysis  compares  the 
average price of monthly water consumption to average monetary income in areas classified 
“urban” for areas conceived to be under AWSC service, and “rural” for areas outside AWSC 
coverage. These values were found to be within acceptable limits of 5% of household income. 
For instance, a candidate subproject in the Ararat region reflects revenues sufficient to cover 
O&M costs and depreciation, at affordable tariffs. However, a mechanism for tariff subsidization 
must be established, especially in rural communities, in cases where affordability will limit 
technical  design  options.  The  Government  is  currently  evaluating  various  options  with  the 
assistance of the World Bank. 
  
G.  Risks 
79.  Potential risks associated with the Project include (i) start-up delays caused by AWSC’s 
unfamiliarity with the use of ADB’s Procurement Guidelines, (ii) delays in agreed improvements 
to financial and legal reforms, and (iii) lack of community support for the upward adjustment in 
tariff.   
 
80.  The Project includes the following measures to mitigate these risks: (i) during the Loan 
Fact-Finding Mission, AWSC was given detailed orientation on ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. AWSC has initiated advance procurement actions 
under ADB’s guidance and it will be further trained during the Loan Inception Mission; (ii) ADB’s 
policy dialogue with the Government has focused on the sector improvements and reforms. To 
ensure  its  compliance,  the  Government  will  hold  PGC  meetings  quarterly  to  monitor 
implementation of these reforms within the agreed time frame. The ADB team will consistently 
follow up and work closely with the Government on the agreed actions; (iii) the public outreach 
program—including media campaign, community mobilization, and public workshops—will be 
implemented to achieve community awareness and ownership in service delivery. Under this 
program, beneficiaries will be involved in planning, designing, implementing, and O&M of the 
subprojects. Communities will be educated in proper water and hygiene practices, and in their 
responsibilities as beneficiaries to pay for the improved services.

SUMMARY OF THE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR POLICY  
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Following  the  collapse  of  the  Soviet  Union,  the  performance  efficiency  of  water 
management in Armenia declined because of mismanagement by weak institutions, inadequate 
coordination  mechanisms,  and  economic  collapse.  Consequently,  the  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) of water supply and sanitation (WSS) systems throughout the country was 
neglected. Consumers faced serious problems with shortage and poor quality of drinking water, 
and lack of wastewater disposal facilities. In 50 towns and 300 villages, over 60% of the WSS 
infrastructure is in very poor condition and about 50% of the water and sewer networks need 
immediate  replacement.  Mechanical  and  electrical  equipment  is  obsolete  and  the  system 
designs and standards are outdated. Sewer pipes are broken and clogged, and wastewater 
treatment plants are not operating. Unaccounted-for water ranges from 40% to 90% in various 
towns and villages, and most people receive water for only 2–8 hours per day. Water supply is 
not adequately disinfected and further pollution risks exist because of infiltration of groundwater 
into the leak-prone distribution network. About 88% of small rural communities have access to 
piped water systems but only 50% houses have an inside water tap. Similarly, sewer systems, 
septic tanks, and other sanitation facilities are broken and clogged—creating serious health 
risks and environmental hazards. 
2.  To improve WSS services, the Government has implemented comprehensive policy, 
institutional,  and  sector  reforms  by  strengthening  the  legislative  and  regulatory  framework, 
restructuring  sector  institutions,  and  mobilizing  financial  resources  for  infrastructure 
improvement. It also approved the following laws: (i) Water Code (the Code), 2002; (ii) National 
Water Policy (the Policy), 2005; and (iii) National Water Program (the Program), 2006. These 
legal instruments provided the foundation for Armenia’s WSS policy. 
B.  The Water Code   
3.  The main objectives of the Code are (i) the establishment of appropriate water resource 
management mechanisms; (ii) the conservation and protection of water resources including 
mitigation of pollution and consistent maintenance, and ensuring adequate monitoring of water 
standards and overall national water reserve; (iii) to ensure adequate safe supply of drinking 
water supply and its safe disposal, with regulated tariffs in place; (iv) to ensure efficient O&M of 
WSS  systems;  and  (v)  to  ensure  effective  management  for  systematic  development  and 
protection of WSS systems.  
4.  The  Code  required  the  creation  of  several  important  water  management  bodies, 
including  the  (i)  National  Water  Council,  (ii)  Dispute  Resolution  Commission,  (iii)  Water 
Resources Management and Protection Body, (iv) Water Basin Management Bodies, (v) Water 
Systems Management Body, (vi) Board to Regulate Water Users Associations and Federation 
of Water Users Associations, and (vii) Regulatory Commission. The Code sets out the duties, 
functions, and responsibilities of each body. It also calls for the preparation of the Policy and the 
Program, and sets out the principal objectives of each. It covers the conditions for the issuance 
and use of water use permits, and the use and management of state-owned water systems. The 
Code establishes the conditions for setting water quality standards and compliance criteria. An 
important provision of the Code deals with economic incentives, fees, and tariffs for WSS 
systems.

C.  National Water Policy  
 
5.  The main principles of the Policy relevant to the WSS sector are (i) provision of safe 
drinking  water  of  the  required  quantity  and  sanitation  to  meet  the  basic  needs  of  all  the 
population, including socially vulnerable groups; (ii) efficient management of water resources 
and  water  systems  by  the  application  of  water  pricing  criteria;  (iii)  assuring  the  gradual 
introduction  of  a  24-hour  water  supply;  (iv)  maintaining  sanitary  and  hygienic  standards; 
(v) assuring water resources management through “user pays” and “polluter pays” principles 
and cost recovery approaches; and (vi) managing water resources and water systems in a 
transparent and participatory manner, assuring gender policy principles and public participation 
processes. 
 
6.  The Policy sets out the principles for developing the Program. It is envisaged that the 
Program will present and update annually a detailed proposal for national water resources and 
water  systems  development  and  management.  The  Program  will  propose  a  short-term 
(5 years), medium-term (10 years), and long-term (15 years) agenda to include all foreseeable 
water resources and water systems development and management actions.  
 
D.   Institutional Framework 
7.  The  Code  has  enabled  the  creation  of  a  new  institutional  framework  that  is  being 
implemented by three agencies. The Ministry of Nature Protection, through its Water Resources 
Management  Agency,  is  implementing  water  resources  management  and  protection.  The 
Ministry of Territorial Administration, through its State Committee of Water Systems (SCWS), is 
implementing the management and operation of WSS systems. The Public Services Regulatory 
Commission is an independent body responsible for implementing tariff policy, including setting 
tariffs for different types of water use. 
8.  For the WSS sector, the key agency is SCWS. To manage and administer the WSS 
systems, the following five closed joint stock companies have been created.  
 
(i)  Armenian  Water  and  Sewerage  Company  (AWSC)  is  responsible  for  the 
management, operation, maintenance, rehabilitation, improvement, and extension of 
WSS systems and services in 47 towns and more than 300 villages in Armenia. 
Since October 2004, AWSC has been managed and operated by an international 
contractor through a management contract, with a life of 4 years until October 2008 
and  an  option  to  extend  for  a  further  2  years  until  October  2010.  The  private 
management  contractor  undertook  effective  management  measures  that  have 
improved the operational performance of AWSC. To date, the collection rate has 
increased from 59.0% to 82.6%; the proportion of energy in the operation costs 
decreased by 36.2% to 21.5%; metering of connections has increased from 40% to 
71%; and the number of connections has increased from 259,900 to 267,100. 
(ii)  Yerevan Water and Sewerage Company (YWSC) is responsible for the operation, 
management, and maintenance of WSS services in Yerevan and 33 nearby villages. 
Since 2005, YWSC has been managed and operated by an international contractor 
through a lease contract with a life of 10 years until 2015.  
(iii)  Lori  Water  and  Sewerage  Company  (LWSC)  was  established  in  2005  and  is 
responsible for WSS services in Lori region.  
(iv)  Shirak Water and Sewerage Company (SWSC) was established in 2005 and is 
responsible for WSS services in Shirak region. 
(v)  Nor Akunq Water and Sewerage Company (NWSC) was established in 2005 and is 
responsible for WSS services in Nora Akunq region.

joint stock companies and make their own arrangements for WSS services. 
 
E.   Emerging Policy Issues 
10.  Based on the analysis of the Code and the Policy, and discussions with SCWS and 
AWSC, the following issues have been identified. 
11.  Management. In view of the small size of Armenia’s population, the five closed joint 
stock companies lose the benefit of economies of scale, and small regional companies are not 
very  effective  as  operating  costs  are  high  and  local  experience  is  deficient.  Improved 
operational efficiency is considered to be achieved by merging LWSC, SWSC, and NWSC with 
AWSC.  
 
12.  Considering the ongoing improvements in the performance of WSS operation under 
AWSC, through the management contractor, the current management contract needs to be 
extended to 2010 in accordance with the contract option and the company should be prepared 
for a lease contract which could be awarded in 2010 when the management contract expires. 
The 10-year lease will allow preparation of AWSC towards concession, if investment is still an 
issue at that time and operator’s view of concession risks improves. 
 
13.  Community-based  water  systems  are  under-resourced  and  poorly  operated  and 
maintained.  A  local  government  and  community  based  training  program  in  the  operation, 
management, and maintenance of small, community-based water supply systems—covering 
source protection, basic maintenance, financial management, and administration—should be 
implemented to improve operational and maintenance capability and capacity at the local level. 
 
14.  Tariffs.  At  present,  an  inflexible  tariff  structure  applies  a  standard  rate  across  the 
country. The cost of supplying water from a source that requires pumping is higher than the cost 
of supplying water by gravity. This cost difference is not reflected in the tariff, so there is an 
internal cross-subsidy as consumers in low production cost areas subsidize consumers in high 
production cost areas. In general, the tariffs are low and the tariff structure is inadequate. 
Further, the Government has to subsidize the revenue shortfall because of the low collection 
efficiency. There is an urgent need to rationalize the existing tariffs with a adequate tariff 
structure for all type of domestic, commercial, and bulk consumers; meter all the connections; 
and introduce a tariff plan that includes progressive tariff revision, taking into account service 
cost and inflation. This will help ensure the sustainability of the overall WSS operations. All 
these  measures  should  be  linked  with  improved  service  delivery  and  sound  operational 
management to ensure people’s willingness to pay. 
 
15.  Legal Framework. Existing contracts between service providers and municipalities do 
not  fully  define  delineation  and  compensation  of  long-term  investments  made  by  service 
providers in assets leased from municipalities. This kind of legal deficiency brings uncertainty 
into the service providers’ long-term financial positions and capital budgeting. Further, existing 
legislation does not grant adequate legal powers to service providers to penalize defaulters of 
WSS bills.  
 
16.  Current  tax  legislation  is  rigid  and  does  not  allow  service  providers  to  use  rapid 
amortization of equipment purchase, limiting companies’ ability to mobilize financial resources 
for timely asset replacement and capital repair. The Government plans to address these gaps in 
the near future.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  This  summary  initial  environmental  examination  (SIEE)  analyzes  the  potential 
environmental  impacts  associated  with  the  Project’s  water  and  wastewater  infrastructure 
improvements, based on the initial environmental examination (IEE) reports prepared for the 
two  candidate  subprojects  during  the  processing  of  the  Project.  The  Project  is  classified 
category B under the guidelines of the Asian Development Bank (ABD). According to ADB 
policy  for  category  B  projects,  an  IEE  is  required  as  the  first  stage  in  developing  an 
environmental assessment. The Law on Environmental Impact Expertise requires upgrading of 
infrastructure projects such as this to be subjected to environmental assessment. 
2.  The  Project  has  taken  a  sector  approach  and  IEEs  have  been  prepared  for  two 
candidate  subprojects—one  core  town  subproject  located  in  Abovyan  and  five  subproject 
villages  located  in  the  Ararat  Marz  (province)  for  the communities  of  Surenavan,  Armash, 
Eraskh, Lanjar, and Paruyr Sevak. No significant adverse environmental impacts were noted in 
any of the subprojects analyzed. Minor environmental impacts identified can be readily mitigated 
using proven technology and construction contract and management measures. The IEEs for 
these subprojects were reviewed by ADB. Implementation of these subprojects will be subject to 
the  approval  of  these  IEEs  by  the  Ministry  of  Nature  Protection  (MNP).  Based  on  the 
environmental assessment and review procedures (Supplementary Appendix H), which have 
been  prepared  in  accordance  with  applicable  government  and  ADB  environmental 
requirements, IEEs will be conducted for the remaining subprojects as part of feasibility studies 
and submitted to the Ministry of Nature Protection for approval before implementation. The IEEs 
for the first subproject and all subprojects above $2 million will require ADB approval. 
 
B.  Description of the Project 
3.  The  principle  outcome  of  the  Project  is  improved  access  to  safe,  reliable,  and 
sustainable water supply and sanitation (WSS) services. Project components comprise two 
parts: (i) rehabilitation and extension of distribution systems, and (ii) improvement of sewerage 
systems. The first part will address rehabilitation and replacement of the deteriorated existing 
water supply infrastructure. The second part will address improvement of the sewerage system 
by cleaning existing sewers and carrying out urgent repairs/replacement of damaged sewers 
that are polluting water supplies in selected towns and villages. 
4.  Lack of water supply is a major problem in the two candidate subprojects, as analyzed 
in Abovyan and the rural communities in Ararat Valley. In Abovyan, 50-year old pipelines are in 
dire need of rehabilitation and inoperable pumps urgently need repair. Over 70% of the total 
water supply is lost through leakage caused by old water supply infrastructure, and the water 
supply is only available intermittently for 4–6 hours per day. Further, the rural communities of 
Surenavan, Armash, Eraskh, Lanjar, and Paruyr Sevak studied in the IEE analysis have not had 
constant water supply in more than 15 years since the collapse of the Soviet Union.  
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
5.  Armenia is a landlocked country in Asia Minor between the Black and Caspian seas, 
bordered by Georgia on the north, Azerbaijan on the east, Iran on the south, and Turkey on the 
west.  The  subproject  town  of  Abovyan  receives  an  average  of  550  millimeters  (mm)  of 
precipitation  per  year  and  has  temperatures  ranging  from  –10˚C  to  25˚C.  The  subproject 
villages located in Ararat Valley have a dry (average of 225 mm per year) and hot climate 
(average temperature of 40˚C). The mountainous communities located on the border of Armenia 
and Azerbaijan have colder temperatures ranging from –16˚C to 20˚C and average precipitation 
of 600 mm.

6.  Springs and groundwater are the primary sources for the water supply systems in the

7.  With the proposed water supply sources, no foreseen water quality issues need to be 
mitigated because the water quality is good or proposed treatment measures are to be taken 
under the Project. On-site wastewater treatment facilities, if in place, lack maintenance and 
basic hygiene requirements. In Abovyan, the sewer lines and sewerage collectors are in need of 
rehabilitation. Within the communities, there is basic sewage system infrastructure including a 
common septic tank, pipes to discharge wastewater into storm water drains for dilution or open-
pit latrines.  
 
8.  The  Project  includes  poor  communities.  In  the  candidate  subproject  communities,      
75–90% of families receive subsidies from the Government. Approximately 80–90% of the 
members of the community farm a small number of livestock or produce crops. The towns and 
communities have basic schools and limited medical facilities. Overall, populations are stable or 
decreasing. 
 
9.  IEE fieldwork and interviews did not reveal concern with vegetation at the subproject 
sites, as it is of low value and can be regrown easily. There are no cultural archeological or

16.  For  the  two  subprojects  analyzed  to  date,  ADB  conducted  six  public  consultations

construction of the subprojects. Their greatest environmental concerns included the degradation 
of land, and drinking and irrigation water as well as limited potable water service. Continuous 
public consultation with the project-affected communities will be carried out during the detailed 
design and implementation period to address their concerns through sustainable designs and by 
keeping the communities involved at all project stages.

17.  The proposed Project is unlikely to cause any adverse environmental impacts because 
(i) potential negative impacts associated with the design, construction, and operation of the 
proposed subproject activities are likely to be temporary and localized in extent, and can be 
mitigated to acceptable levels using proven technology and management measures; and (ii) an 
environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  was  prepared  to  ensure  environmentally 
sustainable implementation of the subprojects. Based on the findings of the two subproject

warrant a detailed Environmental Impact Assessment.

A.  Introduction 
1.  The economic analysis covers the whole sector Project as well as the representative 
subprojects. It assesses the rationale for government intervention in the sector, its capacity to 
execute the sector investment plan, the plan’s goals, design of the plan, and the implementation 
strategy. 
 
B.  Rationale for Government Intervention 
2.  The rationale for government intervention results from increasing concern over the poor 
condition of water supply services in both urban and rural communities—despite the transfer of 
systems management and operations to private water providers, especially in urban centers. 
Currently,  there  are  five  independent  operators  with  different  types  of  ownership  and 
management. Yerevan Water and Sewerage Company is a private company that operates 
under a lease contract, and covers the capital and adjacent 33 rural communities. Armenian 
Water and Sewerage Company (AWSC) is a state company that operates under a management 
contract with a private operator, and covers 37 towns and 300 communities. The municipal 
enterprises, Lori Water and Sewerage, Shirak Water and Sewerage, and Nor Akunq Water and 
Sewerage are jointly owned by the Government and respective municipalities on a 49–51% 
sharing  basis  and  operate  systems  in  communities  in  their  respective  regions.  Current 
operations  are  continually  plagued  by  high  water  wastage  because  of  deficiencies  in  the 
metering program, and poor cash position caused by a low collection ratio and low water tariffs 
that result in low cost recovery—leading to high reliance on government subventions, either 
through tax discounts or energy cost subsidy, and measures like partial debt relief. 
 
3.  The problems are even more pronounced in rural communities at marz (province) and 
regional levels. By detail, water supply services in these areas are under the responsibility of 
local government or community administration. However, studies show that (i) where such 
centralized systems exist, services continue to deteriorate because little can be done to improve 
and rehabilitate the systems because of lack of funds; and (ii) other sectors vie for whatever is 
available. As most of these supply systems are in various stages of deterioration and some are 
dysfunctional, residents are forced to use alternative, unsafe sources of water. Operated by the 
local government or the communities out of their own budget appropriations, only 2% of the 
water supply infrastructure is in good order, and 63% is of a poor standard and continues to 
provide unreliable water supply. Although 50% of households have access to direct water taps, 
the rest rely on boreholes, public standpipes, and delivered water. The limited number of 
individual  water  taps,  or  their  unavailability,  imposes  substantial  time  and  money  costs  to 
residents who on average, spend between one overhaul. Such systems depend on subsidies to 
cover financial needs for large-scale system repair or extension works. Consequently, under the 
present institutional context, many local government and community-based water systems are 
neither institutionally nor financially independent water operators. Water supply is rationed to a 
few hours a day and schedules are often not met. 
 
4.  Government involvement in the investment plan is justified because there is significant 
scope to improve water supply in both urban and rural communities through the provision of 
financial  and  technical  support  and  institutional  capacity  development  which  only  the 
Government can provide effectively at present. Institutional and economic reforms embedded in 
the decentralization efforts have yet to see results. Although the Government transferred the 
responsibility of managing and operating water supply services through recent policies, there is 
still a need for central level management to develop and address the medium- and long-term 
needs  of  the  water  supply  sector  sufficiently.  The  manifold  problems  characterizing  the

sustainable growth by improving the public health and environment in project towns and villages

rural communities. Major investment programs have been undertaken and are currently ongoing 
in the public utilities sector wherein the Government has recognized the inadequacy of water 
supply systems as well as in the institutional settings in which they operate. Until 2000, the 
Government applied the state budget to finance sector investments in the capital and most 
urban towns and cities, while directing the local administration budget toward funding those for 
rural communities. Since then, it adopted the strategy aimed to carry out reforms in the water 
sphere, which included measures on institutional, legal, economic, and organizational changes 
in future water resources management and water economy. This led to the adoption of the 
decree “On Concept of Reforms of Water Resources and Economy”, 2001, which opened the 
doors for sourcing of internal and external investments to support the plan economically through 
issuance of implementation guidelines. The Water Code, 2002, has brought into legislation the

investment plan and concur with the plan’s goals. By 2012, the Project aims to provide improved

Committee of Water Systems (SCWS) as among those areas in the country with the lowest

cover all operation and maintenance costs and depreciation for rural areas, and debt repayment 
for  urban  areas.  Consistent  with  decentralization  policies,  selected  subprojects  in  rural 
communities will strengthen community ownership of the water supply system, helping improve 
sustainability. Through public outreach programs incorporated in the Project, communities will 
be educated in proper water and hygiene practices, and their responsibilities as beneficiaries.

D.  Subproject Selection Criteria and Design 
8.  Subprojects  will  be  prioritized,  since  the  size  and  scope  of  the  Project  prevent  all 
investments from being undertaken simultaneously. The Government demonstrates, through 
SCWS, its willingness and capability to conduct the selection process by identifying towns,

bulk supply of water from AWSC, and (iii) will be the first priority for project investments in the 
zone not covered by AWSC. 
9.  Foremost, the selection will (i) directly address the basic needs of the population in 
terms of drinking water supply; (ii) reflect the water supply strategies set by the Government, 
including health and sanitation and environmental concerns; (iii) not be in conflict with those 
under other projects; (iv) be justified by a feasibility study that covers technical, institutional, 
economic, financial, environmental, and social aspects; (v) adopt the least-cost solution among 
available alternatives; (vi) be based on the detailed analysis of demand and communities’ 
willingness to pay for improved services; and (vii) be and remain sustainable, given proper 
maintenance. For subprojects covered by AWSC or any of the other water companies, the 
economic criteria include a financial internal rate of return (FIRR) higher than the opportunity 
cost of capital, as well as an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of at least 12% to be 
determined through detailed feasibility study. For selections not covered by any of the water 
companies, the financial viability requirement through the FIRR is waived, but the minimum 
EIRR must be satisfied. 
10.  A structured approach will be adopted for the appraisal and approval of subprojects 
included  in  the  Project.  Subprojects  for  rural  communities  will  be  selected  based  on 
nonavailability of safe and affordable alternative water supply, deficient service where systems 
exist, potential for multiple villages served by a single source, high incidence of waterborne and 
related diseases, and willingness of inhabitants to participate in the Project. Subprojects for 
urban towns will be selected based on proximity to the existing water distribution network, 
deficient water supply service characterized by insufficient quantity (less than a 24-hour service) 
and poor quality, high cost of alternative supplies, and willingness of inhabitants to participate in 
the Project and pay for the service. 
11.  The Project’s selection criteria emphasize inhabitants’ willingness not only to participate
