E.  Subproject Economic Analysis 
14.  At least two alternatives were assessed for each subproject based on the pre-feasibility 
study options in terms of demand, source type and availability, and technical design. The 
optimum  alternative  per  subproject  has  been  selected  for  economic  evaluation.  Standard 
benefit-cost analysis following ADB guidelines has been undertaken to measure the economic 
viability of both subprojects as representative of all the other subprojects for inclusion under the 
Project. 
15.  The major economic benefits assumed for the Project include cost savings on non-
incremental  supply  to  connected  and  unconnected  user  households.  The  non-incremental 
benefits  are  quantified using  the  resource cost  savings approach  for  time  spent  on  water 
collection.  Focus  group  discussions  were  conducted  in  Abovyan  and  Ararat  sample 
communities, which aided in eliciting information on the estimated time spent by household 
members collecting water from available sources, based on distance traveled and the average 
number  of  times  the  activity  is  performed  each  day.  Data  on  average  family  income  and 
minimum wages in the locality have been used to value the cost of the activity. The economic 
costs, consisting of capital investment and operating costs, have been converted from financial 
costs using shadow pricing. The conversion factors applied are based on infrastructure projects 
of similar scope in the Central Asian region. To calculate the EIRR, only resource cost savings 
were used. 
16.  Based on the focus group discussions in the two subprojects, over 50% of households 
indicated that 1–4 hours are spent each day fetching water from available wells, springs, or the 
closest open irrigation canals because of the water shortage. In the Abovyan subproject, rural 
households and those not connected to any piped system spend an average of 1 hour to collect 
water daily. In the five rural communities under the Ararat subproject, households have no 
access to piped water. Most of the households spend an average of 2.5–3.0 hours each day 
collecting  water.  The  incremental  benefits  of  increased  volume  sales  are  based  on  the 
difference between the current level of water usage—at less than 9 cubic meters (m3) per 
household  per  month  in  Ararat  communities  and  22  m3  in  Abovyan—and  the  estimated 
increased consumption as a result of the investments. Detailed demand and willingness to pay 
analysis was conducted, which indicated high willingness to pay for improved services. Several 
communities in the project area are currently paying much higher tariffs for water supply through 
purchase of better quality of water from venders. Selection of future subprojects will be mainly 
based on this analysis to ensure that subprojects are demand-based and will be sustainable 
through users’ commitment to pay for the improved services.

cost, (ii) depreciation, and (iii) loan interest. 
 
C.  Financial Evaluation 
1.  Proposed Tariffs 
10.  In the areas of the Abovyan subproject, households are presently charged AMD140 per 
cubic meter (m3). Water service is 2–6 hours on a good day, with a chance of being rationed 
several days per week. In the five rural communities in the Ararat subproject, households buy 
water from tankers or vendors. Average monthly water expenditure for these households could 
easily  reach  AMD2,000–AMD3,000  or  $6–$9.  In  Abovyan,  average  monthly  household 
consumption  is  about  7  m3,  based  on  individual  metered  connections.  In  the  Ararat 
communities, household consumption of drinking water is 2–3 m3 per month. Water acquired 
from water tankers or vendors is usually for drinking purposes only.

11.  Since the subproject schemes are designed for metered in-yard connections, the tariffs 
are volume-based and structured to prevent wastage. Presently, in the subproject areas, no 
distinction is made on household tariffs as a function of their monthly income. Therefore, the 
same tariffs apply for the different categories of users. However, in the near future, when 
operations will have attained some financial stability, a distinction will have to be made to 
account  for  consumption  levels  and  by  consumer  category.  The  structure  should  aim  to 
differentiate tariffs so that the poor within the community who have lower disposable income will 
at least be able to cover their basic water needs. Higher-income households that generally 
require more, and consequently incur higher marginal costs, should be made to pay more.

17.  From initial field investigations conducted during pre-feasibility study preparation, there

income of potential beneficiaries. To measure affordability, the average monthly water bill is set

4.  Conclusion 
18.  The proposed subprojects for Abovyan and the five rural communities in Ararat are 
found to be financially viable. To ensure sustainability, the proposed tariff schedules will have to 
be followed. Likewise, subsidy requirements during the initial years of operation will have to be 
agreed with the possible source/s. The timely infusion of subsidies is essential to operations, 
and will complement subproject efforts to generate sufficient revenue by proper imposition of the 
required tariffs and their regular collection. Failure to implement these fundamental measures 
would likely only lead again to the state of physical disrepair and very poor financial condition, 
which are familiar characteristics of the water supply sector at present.
